title: Longdendale Trail Walking and Cycle Route

images.title: David Lally / Information sign on Longdendale Trail
images.caption:
Information sign on Longdendale Trail Behind is Bottoms reservoir and the village of Tintwistle.
Longdendale is the name given to the upper valley of the River Etherow.
The trail follows the line of the old Manchester - Sheffield line originally opened in 1845 by the Sheffield, Ashton-Under-Lyne and Manchester Railway. Closed to passengers in 1970 and freight in 1981.

images.title: Chris Wimbush / Longdendale Trail at Woodhead Reservoir
images.caption: Longdendale Trail at Woodhead Reservoir

images.title: SMJ / Road Bridge over the Longdendale Trail
images.caption: Road Bridge over the Longdendale Trail

images.title: Stephen Craven / Longdendale Trail with bridge
images.caption: Trail and bridge.  The bridge is the Hadfield to Padfield road. The trail is part of the Trans-Pennine Route (National Cycle Route 62) and follows the route of the old Great Central Railway.

images.title: Chris Wimbush / Longdendale Trail near Deepclough
images.caption: Near Deepclough

images.title: Chris Wimbush / Path to Longdendale Trail from Padfield
images.caption: From Padfield

images.title: Manchester Warrior / Woodhead Reservoir Overflow Channel
images.caption: Woodhead Reservoir Overflow Channel. This picture shows a brimfull Woodhead Reservoir overflowing into the overflow channel located at the Western end of the reservoir. The dam wall and the concrete overflow channel just downstream of here was substantally strengthened in the late 1980's. In the background is the B6105 road which joins the A628 trunk road at the top of the rise.

description: This splendid cycling and walking trail follows a disused railway line through the Longdendale in the Peak District National Park . The path starts in Hadfield and runs alongside a series of beautiful reservoirs including Bottoms Reservoir , Torside Reservoir , Woodhead Reservoir and Rhodeswood Reservoir before finishing at Salter's Brook. It runs for just over 8 miles on a gradually ascending path which is ideal for both cyclists and walkers. There's also fine views of the lovely rolling hills and countryside for the duration of the route. It's easy to access with a train station and public car park right next to the start point at the western end in Hadfield. The route is part of National Cycle Route 62 which runs for 208 miles from the Lancashire coast at Fleetwood to Selby in North Yorkshire. You could extend your exercise by contuing along the signed route into the Peak District and beyond.
